items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels remain high but have been lowering on the River Thames. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the next few days. No further rain is expected today, 3 October 2024, with a more settled period over the coming days. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 4 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge following the recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours. 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on 04/10/24, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
items.message:
Further property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high along much of the upper River Thames as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Levels on the upper Thames have fallen below threshold, but remain high downstream of Radcot, particularly at Rushey, Shifford and Eynsham locks. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue. No further rain is expected today, 3 October 2024, with a more settled period over the coming days. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 4 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are rising in response to recent heavy rainfall within the catchment. This information is correct as of 15:00pm on Thursday 3rd October. The causeway at Earith has approximately 44 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has 118 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 128 centimetres of water on the road.  Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, Friday 4th October 2024.

items.message:

No further rain is expected today, 3 October 2024, with a more settled period over the coming days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.

We are monitoring the situation. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 4 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are still high but steady on the Lower River Colne and Frays River today, Thursday 3 October.
No property flooding is expected, but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking rivers for blockages. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
The forecast has improved and no further rainfall is expected in the next couple of days. As river levels remain high and we are not expecting much change in the level at the Staines Moor gauge, this message will be updated once per day. 
This message will be updated by 6pm tomorrow, Friday 4 October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60mAOD at 04:15 on 04/10/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 211 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:30 on 04/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 04/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Crane

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area. 
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
We do not expect to see impacts from the high tide this afternoon.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Bourne Brook (Tamworth)
River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of high tides coinciding with high flows from upstream. The next high tide is expected at Kingston and Hampton Wick this afternoon 03/10/24, at 15:15 and is forecast to reach between 4.85 - 5.15 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected early tomorrow morning, 04/10/24, at 03:45 and is forecast to reach between 4.95 - 5.25 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks again and flood low lying land. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 04/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels remain high but are slowly falling at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Levels are likely to remain high until Friday morning, 04/10/24. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. 
No further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 04/10/24, or as the situation changes.

The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island this afternoon 03/10/24, at 14:45 and is forecast to reach between 4.88 - 5.02 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected early tomorrow morning, 04/10/24, at 03:15 and is forecast to reach between 4.93 - 5.12 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks again and flood low lying land. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Milford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected between 09:00 today, 03/10/24, and 23:30 this evening, 03/10/24.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until 23:30 on 03/10/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 03/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End throughout today, Thursday 3 October 2024 and into tomorrow. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 04/10/2024, or before, if the situation changes.

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours.

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Torksey river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday 05/10/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 04/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby, the Mountsorrel to Sileby Road, the B5328 Cossington Road and the access road to Sileby Mill, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes.   
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until 05/10/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by tomorrow morning 09:00 on 04/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until 05/10/2024.

River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 4 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels remain high but are now falling on the upper Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Flooding is still possible through Tuesday and into Wednesday. Property flooding is not expected.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Drier conditions are expected from Tuesday onwards and the situation should improve.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 03/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Cam in Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are falling but remain high. Flooding is possible. Areas most at risk are around the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 04/10/24.

items.description: Burton Trent
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Croxall river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected between 09:00 today, 03/10/24, and 22:00 this evening, 03/10/24.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent.    
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until 22:00 on 03/10/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 03/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are currently falling but a peak of floodwater is moving down the catchment from Newport Pagnell. Flooding is still possible for the next few days while floodwater moves through the system. Areas most at risk are Church Walk, Water Lane, Mill Lane, High Street, King William Close and Hillgrounds Road. The forecast is for no further significant rainfall for the next few days. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 04/10/24.

items.description: Lower Nene
items.message: River levels remain high in the River Nene as a result of recent rainfall in the Lower Nene area, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 04/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying areas close to the River Great Ouse at Stony Stratford
items.message: River levels are falling but remain high. Flooding is still possible for the next few days. Areas most at risk are St Pauls Court, Prospect Road, Willow Lane, High Street, Queen Eleanor Street, Temperance Terrace, Feganâ€™s Court and Ostlers Lane in Stony Stratford, Watermill Lane in Wolverton and Cosgrove Leisure Park. The forecast is for no further significant rainfall for the next few days. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 04/10/24.

items.description: Ash Brook, Ippollitts Brook and River Purwell at Hitchin, Ashbrook, Little Wymondley and Graveley
items.message: River levels are falling but remain high downstream. Flooding is still possible for the next few days. Areas most at risk are Woolgrove Road, Green Lane, Purwell Lane, Brook View, Ninesprings Way and Oakfield Avenue in Hitchin, Stevenage Road in Ashbrook, Stevenage Road, Priory Lane and Elms Close in Little Wymondley, High Street and Church Lane in Graveley. The forecast is for drier conditions for the latter part of the week allowing river levels to fall. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 04/10/24.

items.description: River Great Ouse at Brampton and Godmanchester

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Great Ouse, Barracks Brook, Brampton Brook

items.message: River levels remain high after recent rainfall. Flooding is still possible for the next few days while the rivers drain away from high peak levels. Areas most at risk are Bromholme Lane, Buckden Road, Allens Orchard, Hawkes End, Lenton Close, Layton Crescent, Park Road, roads off of Centenary Way, Elizabethan Way, West End, Hansell Road, properties near North Road and Berry Lane in Godmanchester. The forecast is for no further significant rainfall for the next few days. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 04/10/24.

items.description: River Great Ouse at Little Paxton and Great Paxton
items.message: River levels are high but falling. Flooding is still possible for the next few days while the rivers drain away from high peak levels. Areas most at risk are Skipper Way, Red Admiral Court, Marbled White Court, Hayling Walk and Gordon Road in Little Paxton and River Lane in Great Paxton. The forecast is for no further significant rainfall for the next few days. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 04/10/24.

items.description: River Great Ouse at Southoe, Buckden and The Offords
items.message: River levels remain high but are starting to fall. Flooding is still possible for the next few days while the rivers drain away from high peak levels. Areas most at risk are Broughton Lodge Farm in Southoe, Mill Road in Buckden, High Street in Offord Darcy and Station Lane in Offord Cluny. The forecast is for no further significant rainfall for the next few days. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 04/10/24.

items.description: River Great Ouse at Huntingdon and Hartford
River Trent in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.Â  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.Â  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Â No further rainfall is forecast.Â  
We continue to monitor the situation.Â  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: Lower River Rother
items.message:
River levels are continuing to fall across the catchment and are anticipated to continue falling overnight and into tomorrow, Friday 4th October.

Levels remain high in Woodhouse Ings. Our operatives continue to monitor the situation at the Ings and our pumping operations are continuing.

No further significant rainfall is expected over the coming days and we are continuing to closely monitor the situation.

Surface water is likely to affect low spots on roads; take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on Friday 4th October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rother at Woodhouse Mill
items.message:
This flood warning remains in force due to high river levels following Monday's heavy and persistent rainfall. Areas most at risk include Woodhouse Mill and properties on Furnace Lane and Retford Road.

River levels at the Woodhouse Ings regulator are continuing to drop slowly. Levels upstream at Killamarsh and Meadowgate have returned to normal levels.

With no further significant rainfall forecast over the next few days, levels at Woodhouse are expected to continue to fall overnight and throughout tomorrow, Friday 4th October.

Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not drive through floodwater. To report flooding, call our Incident Hotline on 0800 80 70 60.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message as the situation changes. This message will be updated by 07:00 on 4th October 2024.

items.description: River Rother at Beighton
items.message:
This flood warning remains in force due to high river levels following Monday's heavy and persistent rainfall. Areas most at risk include Beighton, including Woodhouse Lane and Rotherham Road and Crown Works Industrial Estate.

River levels at the Woodhouse Ings regulator are continuing to drop slowly. Levels upstream at Killamarsh and Meadowgate have returned to normal levels.

With no further significant rainfall forecast over the next few days, levels at Beighton are expected to continue to fall overnight and throughout tomorrow, Friday 4th October.

Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not drive through floodwater. To report flooding, call our Incident Hotline on 0800 80 70 60.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message as the situation changes. This message will be updated by 07:00 on 4th October 2024.

items.description: Rase and Upper Ancholme
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Rase and Upper Ancholme has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days."

items.description: River Sence from Temple Mill to Sheepy Magna
Alconbury Brook in Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are steadily falling. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Soar at caravan parks near Barrow upon Soar
items.message:
River levels are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are Proctor's Pleasure Park near Barrow upon Soar.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow, 04/10/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by tomorrow morning 09:00, 04/10/24, or as the situation changes.
